questions.stem: During the initial DSCC call, what information should you gather to triage the case?

options.text: Only the client's name
Client name, alleged offence, custody location, time limits, vulnerability issues, and interview timing
Only the offence type
You don't need to gather information—just attend

questions.explanation: During the initial DSCC call, you should gather key information to triage: client name, alleged offence, custody location, time limits (relevant time, detention limits), any vulnerability issues, and whether an interview is planned. This helps you prioritise, prepare, and identify urgent issues requiring immediate attention.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — authority to act

questions.stem: You arrive at custody after the initial DSCC call. What should be your first steps?

options.text: Go straight to interview
Inspect the custody record, identify vulnerabilities, request disclosure, and assess the situation before taking instructions
Only speak to the police
Wait for the police to tell you what to do

questions.explanation: On arrival, your first steps should be: inspect the custody record (authorisation, reviews, time limits, rights given), identify any vulnerabilities, request disclosure, and assess the situation. Only then should you take instructions from the client. This ensures you have the full picture before advising.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — assessment structure

questions.stem: After interview, your client is bailed with conditions. What should you do?

options.text: Nothing—bail is granted
Make representations on conditions if inappropriate, advise the client on bail conditions and consequences of breach, and complete your records
Only complete records
Only advise on conditions

questions.explanation: After interview and bail decision, you should: make representations on conditions if they are inappropriate or disproportionate, advise the client clearly on what the conditions mean and the consequences of breach, ensure the client understands their obligations, and complete your attendance notes and records. This is part of post-interview outcome management.

questions.stem: Your client is released under investigation (RUI) after interview. What advice should you give?

options.text: RUI means the case is closed—no further action
Explain that investigation continues, they can be re-arrested, they should not discuss the case with others, and they should contact you if re-arrested
Only explain they are free to go
No advice is needed for RUI

questions.explanation: RUI means the investigation continues without bail conditions. You must advise: the case is not closed, they can be re-arrested if further evidence emerges, they should not discuss the case with others (especially co-suspects), they should contact you immediately if re-arrested, and they should keep you informed of any developments. This is crucial client care.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — assessment structure

questions.stem: What should be included in your attendance notes after a CIT scenario?

options.text: Only the client's name and offence
Client details, time of arrival, custody record inspection, disclosure received, instructions taken, advice given, interview attendance, interventions made, outcome, and any issues identified
Only the outcome
Only if something went wrong

questions.explanation: Attendance notes should be comprehensive and contemporaneous, including: client details, time of arrival, what you inspected (custody record), disclosure received, instructions taken, advice given, interview attendance and any interventions, outcome (bail/RUI/charge), and any issues or concerns. This is essential for portfolio building and professional record-keeping.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — record keeping
